newsitem.title: CANADA: GM negotiator says deal reached to end strike.
newsitem.headline: GM negotiator says deal reached to end strike.

text.p: General Motors Corp.'s lead negotiator said Tuesday the automaker and leaders of the Canadian Auto Workers union reached a deal to end the 19-day strike by 26,000 auto workers at GM's Canadian plants.
A union official said earlier that GM had dropped its demand for a mandatory overtime rule at its Oshawa, Ontario, assembly plant, paving the way for a pact.
"We have a new 1996 collective agreement," Canadian Auto Workers President Buzz Hargrove told a news conference.
The issue of mandatory overtime had been the main stumbling block to a deal to end the strike, which has also idled more than 18,000 GM workers in the United States and Mexico.
Asked whether the deal was a win-win compromise, GM's chief negotiator, Dean Munger responded, "Yes, sure is."
"Let's get it ratified, it's a good agreement. It suits our business needs and fits your members' needs," he told the union's negotiating team.
